div1.p: Carter continues to track down references for quotations, particularly dealing with Mayan references for the History of Yellow Fever.

Dear Jack:
div1.p: Your letter of October 19th. just received.

You are correct in assuming that Béranger-Féraud Traité théorique et clinique....(1890) p. 30, in
citing Du Tertre re St. Lucia epidemic (1665) gives no specific reference by
volume or page and cites no authority other than Du Tertre. I hope that
Miss Brown and I can get some satisfactory data on this reference later
on : Had not tried up to the time I got vol. 3 of Du Tertre, in which I
had, of course, expected to get a satisfactory reference. Since, however,
you say we can disregard it, I shall postpone further investigation un-
til we have straightened up some more of the long verbatim quotations from
the latter part of the MSS and also those wretchéd Mayan references, on
which we have almost no data. Of course, we have verified most of the
Mayan refs., but the remaining ones are very troublesome and Father's
notes, beautifully clear and full about some things, give us no help
on what remains to be cleared up. When I think of Morley, and how easily
he could have straightened things out, I'm glad to see the Episcopal
House of Delegates, yesterday, went on record as being opposed to the
abolition of capital punishment. He may “get his” yet!

By the way, re Lassis (ii, 57) re epidemic Paris (1822) fever with jaundic)e: black vomit and
petechiae (1822) Paris, although La Roche gives Lassis' “Calamités[unclear]tc.”
